questions.stem: In horses, “choke” refers specifically to:

options.label: A
options.text: Obstruction of the trachea by feed material

options.label: B
options.text: Partial or complete obstruction of the esophagus by feed or foreign material

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction of the nasal passages by mucus

options.label: D
options.text: Spasm of the laryngeal muscles

questions.explanation: In horses, “choke” refers specifically to esophageal obstruction by feed or foreign material, not tracheal obstruction (A) or nasal/laryngeal problems (C, D).

questions.stem: Why is esophageal obstruction (“choke”) considered a true veterinary emergency?

options.label: A
options.text: It always causes sudden cardiac arrest

options.label: B
options.text: It inevitably leads to laminitis

options.label: C
options.text: It carries risks of aspiration pneumonia and esophageal rupture

options.label: D
options.text: It is highly contagious between horses

questions.explanation: Choke is a true emergency because of serious risks such as aspiration pneumonia and possible esophageal rupture. It does not invariably cause cardiac arrest (A), laminitis (B), or contagion (D).

questions.stem: Which horses are MOST at risk of developing choke?

options.label: A
options.text: Only young foals on milk replacer

options.label: B
options.text: Only racehorses in intense training

options.label: C
options.text: Horses eating dry/coarse feeds quickly, especially with poor dentition

options.label: D
options.text: Horses on pasture only with no supplemental feed

questions.explanation: Horses that bolt dry/coarse feeds (pellets, hay cubes, large vegetable pieces), particularly with poor dentition, are at high risk. It is not confined to foals (A), racehorses (B), or pasture‑only horses (D).

questions.stem: Regarding signalment, which statement is MOST accurate for choke?

options.label: A
options.text: Only older draft horses are affected

options.label: B
options.text: Only miniature horses are affected

options.label: C
options.text: Any age and breed can be affected, with higher risk in older horses with dental issues and greedy eaters

options.label: D
options.text: Only stallions are affected

questions.explanation: Any breed or age can be affected, but the risk is higher in older horses with poor teeth and in greedy eaters or those with esophageal disease. The other options restrict the condition to specific groups (A, B, D), which is incorrect.

questions.stem: Primary choke is BEST defined as:

options.label: A
options.text: Esophageal obstruction due to external compression by a mass

options.label: B
options.text: Obstruction caused by a feed bolus or foreign material directly blocking the esophagus

options.label: C
options.text: Obstruction secondary to laryngeal paralysis

options.label: D
options.text: Obstruction due to congenital vascular ring anomalies

questions.explanation: Primary choke occurs when a feed bolus or foreign object itself obstructs the esophageal lumen. External compression (A), laryngeal paralysis (C), or vascular ring anomalies (D) describe other pathologies.

questions.stem: Secondary choke is typically associated with:

options.label: A
options.text: Primary gastric ulcers

options.label: B
options.text: Structural or functional esophageal problems such as strictures, megaesophagus, or tumors

options.label: C
options.text: Lung abscesses compressing the trachea

options.label: D
options.text: Primary neurologic disease of the spinal cord only

questions.explanation: Secondary choke arises from underlying esophageal structural or functional abnormalities (strictures, megaesophagus, tumors), which then predispose to obstruction. Gastric ulcers, lung abscesses, or spinal cord disease (A, C, D) are not typical primary causes.

questions.stem: Which is NOT listed as a common contributing factor to choke?

options.label: A
options.text: Horses eating large, dry, coarse feed pieces quickly

options.label: B
options.text: Poor dentition and missing teeth in older horses

options.label: C
options.text: Sedation that reduces esophageal motility

options.label: D
options.text: Excessive grooming and brushing of the coat

questions.explanation: Rapid intake of large, dry, coarse feeds, poor dentition, and sedation reducing esophageal motility are recognized contributors; grooming (D) is unrelated. Thus D is correctly identified as NOT a factor.

questions.stem: A classic early clinical sign of choke in the horse is:

options.label: A
options.text: Profuse watery diarrhea

options.label: B
options.text: Discharge of saliva and feed material from the nostrils or mouth, often green and frothy

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral epistaxis with no swallowing difficulty

options.label: D
options.text: Sudden blindness with normal appetite

questions.explanation: Classic choke produces green, frothy saliva and feed material from the nostrils or mouth due to retrograde flow and inability to swallow. Diarrhea (A), pure epistaxis (C), or blindness (D) are not typical.

questions.stem: Which behavior is commonly observed in horses experiencing choke?

options.label: A
options.text: Persistent head pressing in a corner

options.label: B
options.text: Coughing, gagging, repeated attempts to swallow, and stretching or elongating the neck

options.label: C
options.text: Constant circling in the stall

options.label: D
options.text: Prolonged recumbency without movement

questions.explanation: Horses with choke often cough, gag, repeatedly attempt to swallow, and extend or stretch the neck in discomfort. Head pressing, circling, or prolonged recumbency (A, C, D) are not characteristic primary signs.

questions.stem: A “visible lump” along the side of the neck in a horse with choke typically represents:

options.label: A
options.text: Enlarged lymph nodes due to infection

options.label: B
options.text: Local muscle hypertrophy

options.label: C
options.text: The obstructing bolus in the cervical esophagus

options.label: D
options.text: Thrombosed jugular vein

questions.explanation: A visible swelling along the cervical esophagus usually corresponds to the obstructing bolus. Enlarged nodes (A), muscle hypertrophy (B), or jugular thrombosis (D) have different appearances and contexts.

questions.stem: Untreated or poorly managed choke can lead to which MAJOR complication?

options.label: A
options.text: Gastric volvulus

options.label: B
options.text: Aspiration pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: Laminitis within hours

options.label: D
options.text: Corneal ulcers

questions.explanation: Aspiration pneumonia is a major, potentially life‑threatening complication when feed or saliva enters the lungs. Gastric volvulus (A), immediate laminitis (C), or corneal ulcers (D) are not primary consequences.

questions.stem: Esophageal scarring and strictures after a choke episode are clinically important because:

options.label: A
options.text: They permanently prevent swallowing

options.label: B
options.text: They predispose the horse to recurrent choke episodes

options.label: C
options.text: They cause immediate weight gain

options.label: D
options.text: They protect the esophagus from future damage

questions.explanation: Post‑obstruction scarring and strictures narrow the lumen, making future obstructions more likely. They do not necessarily cause total permanent dysphagia (A), weight gain (C), or protection (D).

questions.stem: The initial diagnosis of choke is primarily based on:

options.label: A
options.text: History and characteristic clinical signs confirmed by veterinary physical examination

options.label: B
options.text: Fecal flotation and culture

options.label: C
options.text: Lung biopsy and bronchoscopy

options.label: D
options.text: Only radiographs of the abdomen

questions.explanation: Diagnosis is usually made from history plus classic clinical signs and physical exam findings localizing the obstruction. Fecal tests, lung biopsy, or abdominal radiographs alone (B–D) are inadequate or unrelated.

questions.stem: Which diagnostic tools may be used to further characterize an esophageal obstruction in horses?

options.label: A
options.text: Endoscopy via the nose into the esophagus and radiography

options.label: B
options.text: CT scanning of the head only

options.label: C
options.text: Arthroscopy of the limb joints

options.label: D
options.text: Gastroscopy of the stomach only

questions.explanation: Endoscopy through the nose into the esophagus and radiography can help confirm and characterize the obstruction. CT, arthroscopy, or gastroscopy alone (B–D) are not primary tools for choke evaluation.

questions.stem: As an immediate emergency step when choke is suspected, owners should:

options.label: A
options.text: Offer water and soaked feed to help “wash down” the obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: Keep the horse eating to stimulate esophageal motility

options.label: C
options.text: Call a veterinarian immediately, withhold food and water, and remove any feed from the mouth

options.label: D
options.text: Administer oral mineral oil without veterinary advice

questions.explanation: Owners should contact a veterinarian immediately, withhold food and water, remove visible feed from the mouth, and keep the horse calm. Encouraging eating/drinking (A, B) or administering unprescribed oral agents (D) may worsen the situation.

questions.stem: Why should horses with choke not be allowed to drink or eat until evaluated?

options.label: A
options.text: It increases the chance of the obstruction moving upward

options.label: B
options.text: It can worsen the obstruction and increase the risk of aspiration pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: It has no effect on outcome

options.label: D
options.text: It causes esophageal hypothermia

questions.explanation: Allowing feed or water can increase the size of the bolus and greatly raises the risk of aspiration pneumonia if material spills into the trachea. It does not reliably “float” the obstruction away (A).

questions.stem: Gentle massage along the jugular furrow toward the heart in a choke case is intended to:

options.label: A
options.text: Move the obstruction caudally in the esophagus

options.label: B
options.text: Stimulate carotid baroreceptors

options.label: C
options.text: Increase heart rate and blood pressure

options.label: D
options.text: Remove gas from the rumen

questions.explanation: Gentle downward massage along the jugular furrow may help move the obstructing bolus caudally toward the stomach. It is not intended to alter baroreceptors, cardiovascular parameters, or rumen gas (B–D).

questions.stem: Pharmacologic management of choke may include:

options.label: A
options.text: Muscle relaxants/antispasmodics such as N‑butylscopolammonium bromide to aid esophageal motility

options.label: B
options.text: Only diuretics to reduce edema

options.label: C
options.text: High‑dose corticosteroids as the sole therapy

options.label: D
options.text: Anthelmintics to paralyze parasites

questions.explanation: Antispasmodics such as N‑butylscopolammonium bromide are used to relax the esophagus and facilitate passage of the obstruction. Diuretics, sole corticosteroid use, or dewormers (B–D) are not mainstays of choke treatment.

questions.stem: Esophageal flushing in choke treatment is BEST described as:

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid high‑pressure water lavage without sedation

options.label: B
options.text: Careful irrigation of the esophagus under sedation using a stomach tube and controlled fluid flow

options.label: C
options.text: Use of compressed air to blow out the obstruction

options.label: D
options.text: Surgical removal of the esophagus

questions.explanation: Esophageal flushing is a controlled, low‑pressure irrigation of the esophagus under sedation, typically via a stomach tube, to gradually break up and move the obstruction. High‑pressure lavage, compressed air, or esophagectomy (A, C, D) are unsafe or inappropriate.

questions.stem: Surgical intervention (e.g., esophagostomy) for choke in horses is:

options.label: A
options.text: Routine first‑line therapy

options.label: B
options.text: Rare and reserved for refractory or complicated cases

options.label: C
options.text: Contraindicated in all horses

options.label: D
options.text: Used only for foals

questions.explanation: Surgery is rarely needed and reserved for refractory cases, complications, or specific structural problems. It is not routine first‑line (A) and is not absolutely contraindicated (C).

questions.stem: Which medications are commonly used as adjuncts in the management of choke?

options.label: A
options.text: NSAIDs for pain and inflammation, antibiotics if aspiration or mucosal damage is suspected, and sedatives to calm the horse

options.label: B
options.text: Only topical ointments applied to the neck

options.label: C
options.text: High‑dose oral electrolytes only

options.label: D
options.text: Long‑term diuretic therapy alone

questions.explanation: NSAIDs manage pain and inflammation, antibiotics are used when aspiration or mucosal injury is suspected, and sedatives allow safe handling and treatment. Topicals, electrolytes, or diuretics alone (B–D) do not address the core issues.

questions.stem: After the obstruction has been cleared, appropriate recovery and follow‑up care include:

options.label: A
options.text: Immediate return to dry pellets and unrestricted exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Short period of fasting followed by easy‑to‑chew or soaked feeds while the esophagus heals, with monitoring for signs of aspiration pneumonia

options.label: C
options.text: Only pasture grass and no monitoring

options.label: D
options.text: Forced exercise to prevent re‑obstruction

questions.explanation: After clearance, horses should receive easily swallowed, soaked or soft feeds while the esophagus heals and be monitored for aspiration pneumonia. Abrupt return to dry feeds and intense exercise (A), pasture only with no monitoring (C), or forced exercise (D) are inappropriate.

questions.stem: Which preventive strategy helps reduce the risk of choke in horses receiving dry feeds such as pellets or hay cubes?

options.label: A
options.text: Avoid soaking feeds to maintain texture

options.label: B
options.text: Soak dry feeds so they are softer and easier to swallow

options.label: C
options.text: Provide only straw bedding for roughage

options.label: D
options.text: Restrict water before and after feeding

questions.explanation: Soaking pellets, beet pulp, and hay cubes softens them, making them safer to swallow and less likely to lodge. Avoiding soaking (A), using straw (C), or restricting water (D) can increase risk.

questions.stem: Regular dental care helps prevent choke primarily by:

options.label: A
options.text: Whitening the horse’s teeth

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring efficient chewing and reduction of large, poorly chewed feed boluses

options.label: C
options.text: Preventing gum infections only

options.label: D
options.text: Increasing saliva production regardless of chewing

questions.explanation: Proper dental care improves mastication and reduces large, poorly chewed feed boluses that can cause obstruction. Cosmetic changes or gum infection prevention alone (A, C) are not the key antichoke benefits.

questions.stem: For known “fast eaters” or horses with a history of choke, which management changes are recommended?

options.label: A
options.text: Feeding large meals once daily in a small bucket

options.label: B
options.text: Slowing intake by adding rocks or salt blocks to the feed pan, using hay nets, spreading forage, reducing competition, and feeding at natural head height

options.label: C
options.text: Withholding forage entirely

options.label: D
options.text: Feeding in a high‑mounted manger to speed swallowing

questions.explanation: Slowing intake with rocks or salt blocks in the pan, using hay nets, spreading forage, reducing competition, feeding at ground level/natural posture, and consulting a nutritionist are all recommended. Large single meals (A), removing forage (C), or high mangers (D) are counterproductive.
